subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Sai (weapon)}} [[File:Antique_Okinawan_sai.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|釵}} (''sai''): An [[antique]] [[Okinawa]]n '''sai'''.]] {{commonscat|Sai}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=さい}} {{m|ltc|釵|tr=*chrɛi}}. Compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|釵|tr=chāi|hairpin; sai (weapon)}}. This character was originally used in Japanese to mean ({{m|en|ornamental}}) {{m|en|hairpin}}, and was read with a [[訓読み#Japanese|''kun'yomi'']] of ''kanzashi''. The similarity in shape between a hairpin and the weapon called a ''sai'' later led to this character being used to refer to the weapon. In modern Japanese, this character is read primarily with its [[音読み#Japanese|''on'yomi'']] of ''sai'', and is used to refer to the weapon. The {{m|en|hairpin}} sense and ''kanzashi'' reading are more often spelled {{m|ja|簪}}.

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|さい}}

# {{lb|ja|weaponry|sort=さい}} a ''sai'': a short [[blunt]] weapon with a wide [[guard]], used mainly for defense against opponents armed with swords

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|簪|簪 (''kanzashi'')}} {{wikipedia|Kanzashi}} [[File:Fukuyu with willow kanzashi.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|釵}} (''kanzashi''): A {{m|ja|舞子|tr=maiko||apprentice ''geisha''}} with the [[willow]]-themed ''kanzashi'' for the month of June.]] {{commonscat|Kanzashi}}
{{IPAchar|/kamusaɕi/}} → {{IPAchar|/kanzaɕi/}} Originally a compound of {{compound|ja|sort=かんざし|髪|tr1=kamu|t1=hair, hair of the head|pos1={{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=かんざし}} combining form|挿し|tr2=sashi|t2=sticker-through (something that sticks through)|pos2=the {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{ja-l|挿す}} ''sasu'' “to stick through, to insert”}}.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}{{R:Daijirin}} {{rendaku2|sort=かんざし|sashi|zashi}}

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|かんざし}}

# a [[hairpin]], particularly a [[fancy]] [[decorative]] hairpin used in Japanese women's [[hairstyle]]s

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: This sense is more commonly spelled in kanji as {{ja-l|簪}} or in kana as {{ja-l|かんざし}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 3
subSections.text:
May be a sound shift from ''kanzashi''.<ref name="KDJ"/>

{{IPAchar|/kanzaɕi/}} → {{IPAchar|/kazaɕi/}}

Alternately, this may be a compound of {{compound|ja|sort=かざし|髪|tr1=ka|t1=hair|pos1=[[w:Apophony|apophonic]] form of {{ja-l|毛}} ''ke'' “hair”|挿し|tr2=sashi|t2=sticker-through}}.<ref name="KDJ"/>

A folk etymology occasionally encountered is that this as a compound of {{m|ja|花|tr=ka||flower}} + {{m|ja|挿し|tr=sashi||sticker-through}}, as many decorative hairpins have floral themes. However, this etymology would mix the Chinese-derived [[音読み#Japanese|''on'yomi'']] of ''ka'' and the {{etyl|ojp|-}}-derived [[訓読み#Japanese|''kun'yomi'']] of ''sashi'', which seems less probable than the above two possibilities.

subSections.title: Related terms
subSections.text: * {{ja-r|挿頭す|かざす}}: to [[stick]] in one's hair (as for [[decoration]]); to add decoration on top of something
